My ambition is to see the rates replaced by some other system of local taxation, but the position is that because of the type of malicious injuries occurring something has got to be done, and the Minister for Justice is doing it.

The extraordinary thing about malicious damage is that in most cases nobody sees it done. The ratepayer complains, and rightly so; everybody, including Members of this House, complain because they have to pay more money by way of rates, but these are the people who stand by and see young hooligans smashing public and private property and make no effort to bring the matter to the notice of the authorities. This is quite wrong and the sooner we get a little more public spirit about this sort of thing the better it will be for all concerned. The number involved in this type of hooliganism is relatively small. They constitute a small group in this city and in other cities and towns throughout the country. These are the people who are consistently damaging property. Yet, nobody sees them do it. We hear about the telephone kiosks smashed up and when we talk about it everyone clamps down as soon as the question of names comes up. Now we cannot have it both ways and, if we want to put an end to the type of damage for which ratepayers are paying so heavily, we will have to stand up to it and ensure that these small groups of vandals every-where are named and dealt with as they should be dealt with.

Deputy Leonard referred to the bomb damage in Monaghan. He can be assured that the cases he referred to are covered by this legislation. I was afraid for a moment he was going to go a little bit too far. I rather felt he was a person with very large stones in his pocket and a very small glass-house around him.

Deputy Brugha also referred to the delay in making payments. Let me repeat that the delay will now be con-considerably reduced. The ambition is to see it reduced as much as possible so that those who get a court order will be paid as quickly as possible.

Deputy Dowling wanted to know what type of malicious injury is going to be certified. If I were to make any forecast on that, I would be prejudging what the chief superintendent will decide and I should not like to tie his hand since anything I might say here might prevent him making the decision he intended to make. I hasten to add that I have a great respect for the Garda. A number of Deputies referred to lobbying. We are lobbied and they are lobbied. A person who has a job to do and has not got the moral courage to do it as it should be done, irrespective of whether or not he is lobbied, is not fit for the position he is in. I believe a chief superintendent, no matter what lobbying is done, will always make his decision fairly. I would trust all chief superintendents to do that. Should it turn out subsequently that I am wrong, then we can have another look at this. By passing this on to the chief superintendent we are putting people in the position in which those who are entitled to be paid will be paid without further delay.

Deputy O'Malley and others commented on the provision of £1 million. It was suggested that this looked as if claims would not be processed this year. The way things go I will be very surprised if claims are processed this year. We have only another six months left. We could have put in a token Estimate for £10. What we did was to put in an Estimate for £1 million because half the year has gone and we thought £1 million should be sufficient for the moment. If it is not we will bring in another Supplementary Estimate. There is no mystery about this. We are dealing with it in a very reasonable way.
Once more, I thank the House for dealing with this matter so expeditiously.

Speaker.P: In relation to the chief superintendent, could he not make a decision before the court comes to a decision?

One of the reasons why it is the chief superintendent is that, in the course of his investigation of the case, he must know all the facts. I think Deputy Dowling asked who caused the trouble in Dublin. I do not know and I do not believe anybody knows with certainty. The people who will be able to give us the best idea as to who did it are the Garda. The chief superintendent will be acting on that at present.
Supposing they did not use explosives.
This deals with explosives specifically. There is a reason for that.
Did the Minister deal with independent assessors?

I did. The reason why we have not suggested independent assessors is that we want a quick decision. If they were involved it could mean a delay of a month or two months or six months while an assessment was carried out. We are suggesting the person who will be responsible for the investigation of the actual crime in the area and who, therefore, should have first-hand knowledge as to who was responsible for it. If that does not work out, we are prepared to have another look at it. We suggest this is the best way because it will mean that those who have got decrees and who have not been paid — that is most of the people concerned — will now be able to get their money immediately following the report from the superintendent. With an assessor or a number of assessors it could take months on end.
I think the Minister misunderstood my question. I meant that when the claim comes in the assessor will see whether the estimate given by the contractor——

On the question of deciding whether the claim was fair, the court is the assessor. That is why it is sent to the court rather than making a decision outside the court. In the new legislation dealing with malicious damage which will be coming before the House shortly I have suggested that, perhaps, the question of fraudulent claims might be included. That is one way in which what Deputy Briscoe is talking about could be dealt with.
I would be in favour of that.

In relation to the opinion of the chief superintendent the words used are “attributable to the disturbances in Northern Ireland”. Must the opinion of the chief superintendent be that they are? Supposing he is not able to give an opinion.

We do not want a situation to arise where a person can throw a couple of sticks of gelignite into a supermarket or a ballroom which is not paying and make a claim against the State. I would not like to prejudge the position.
Fair enough.
Vote put and agreed to.
Vote reported and agreed to.

MainHeading.Title: Committee on Finance. - Estimates, 1974.
MainHeading.P: The Dáil, according to order, went into Committee on Finance and resumed consideration of Estimates for Public Services for April-December, 1974.

MainHeading.Title: Committee on Finance. - Vote 43: Posts and Telegraphs (Resumed).
MainHeading.P: Debate resumed on the following motion:

That a sum not exceeding £48,619,000 be granted to defray the charge which will come in course of payment during the period commencing on the 1st day of April, 1974, and ending on the 31st day of December, 1974, for the salaries and expenses of the Office of the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs and of certain other services administered by that Office, and for payment of certain grantsin-aid.
—(Minister for Posts and Telegraphs)

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: In this Department above all others a tribute is due to the staff on the public relations duties they carry out. In no other Government Department have the staff so many daily communications with the general public. It happens across the counter, on the doorstep on a cold, wet and wintry morning, at the telephone exchanges, and so on. The staff in the Department of Posts and Telegraphs at all levels deserve a very high tribute from all of us. I am sure many of us can be difficult and hard to please. We do not like taking our place in queues and at times we get a bit annoyed about it. We do not like waiting for telephone calls, and so on. I am sure we are not always as nice and as civil to them as we should be.

The buildings and the office conditions should be improved continually and should be brought up to a standard which would be conducive to having these people working in a happy atmosphere. I was a bit dis-appointed with the low key of the Minister's speech. It is not in line with what we have come to expect from the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs. I am sorry he is not here.
He is at a Government meeting. He will be here.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: It is not what we have come to expect from him in recent months——
Wait until you hear his high key reply.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: ——judging by the announcements and the pronouncements he has made in all sorts of places outside the House. His statements in the House for the most part have been in a low key. The Minister more than anybody else likes controversy, and likes to be controversial, and likes to make the headlines. His opening speech on this Estimate was not headline seeking.

MainHeading.P: I found it very strange coming from him, but he devoted about two and a half pages of his speech to the pay increases of the staff. He referred at length to the increasing costs of the Department and the reasons for those increasing costs. He referred to the fact that the national wage agreement was contributing so much at present and would contribute so much later on this year and in the coming years to the increasing costs of his Department.

He addressed an aside to the unions which I thought was unbecoming to him, particularly coming from the party he represents. He said that the national wage agreement having been implemented other requests were being made which also put up staff costs. He said:
With the emergence of national wage agreements securing general increases for all staff, unions are in a position to concentrate——
I think this is a subtle criticism of the unions
——on claims for special increases for more pay or improved conditions supplemental to the increases provided for in the national agreements.
Reading between the lines here the Minister is saying in a very subtle way that the unions representing the members of the staff are not entitled to make such claims.

Speaker.P: I used the Minister's script at the annual dinner of the Post Office workers last night in Waterford and I used that phrase and I was roundly applauded.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: The Minister used the sentence I read?
That is right.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Some of them may have been enjoying themselves too well and were not able to absorb it as I absorbed it.
They were not.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: If I told them what I read into it they would not applaud.
They are intelligent people. They are able to make up their own minds.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: In the Minister's very able way he may have laid the emphasis on words which might give it a slightly different meaning.
It must have a different meaning so.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: The Minister said that the unions are in a position to concentrate on claims for special increases. Here we have the Minister of a Department, the boss, the man in charge of the Department, speaking on this subject. The Minister devoted two and a half pages to this culminating on the beautiful point that no major economies can be achieved in the short term without curtailment of services and a discharge of staff.
Exactly that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: The atmosphere there must have been very good but I would interpret this as possibly a threat from the Minister to these people to go a little easy on their demands on him or he is saying to the general public that he either gives the increases or lays off staff or the people of Ireland will have to pay more for the postal services. The Minister is telling us that this present Government, under whom we have seen prices escalating since February of last year, because of increasing costs will have to come in with another mini-budget to meet the rising costs in his Department.
The Deputy is not in favour of wage increases?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Certainly I am in favour of wage increases but I am not in favour of price increases.
So it is the Deputy's opinion that increases should be given but that they should not be paid for.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: The Minister for Local Government and his colleagues from many platforms in February, 1973, described the general election as a “bread and butter” election.
These are matters for another Estimate and we cannot have a debate on prices today.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: We have the Minister plugging and trying to pad the way for increased charges for Post Office services to the general public. He has spent two and a half pages bemoaning and begroaning the fact that wage increases are soaring. When I read this, it reminded me of what one would have expected from one of the big Dublin bosses, or big Dublin employers, in the pre-1913 period. This is something the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs would not like me to think of him but it is the impression he creates in my mind. He created the impression that here was the big boss, the man in authority, a member of the Labour Party, telling the staff of the post offices throughout the country that it was wrong for them to be seeking increases over and above the national wage agreement. I hope I am wrong in my interpretation of it because I would be amazed that a Minister would have that idea.
In fairness to the Minister concerned, would the Deputy read the second paragraph on page 18 because it is wrong to take these things out of context.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I have read it fully but the overall impression must come across that here is the big boss waving the stick and stating that his costs are soaring because his boys are looking for more money.
The Minister concerned states on page 18 that he recognises their right to do this.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Agreed, but he goes on to bemoan and begroan just like one of the 1913 big bosses would have done in Dublin city. He throws in that but he goes on from there to complain about these increasing costs.

MainHeading.P: In my view the staff of the Department of Posts and Telegraphs have given, and are giving, an excellent service to the general public. I should like to mention in particular the ladies and gentlemen who man telephone exchanges and the postmen in rural areas who work under very trying conditions. They are deserving of our appreciations. On the question of postal deliveries the Minister has mentioned that we now have 650 motorised units representing 45 per cent of the total mileage covered by the postal service. In my opinion this is inadequate progress and progress too slow. If we take it that 55 per cent of the mileage covered by the Department of Posts and Telegraphs in postal deliveries is still being operated by people on foot or on bicycles, then the progress is not adequate. I accept that the progress was slowed down during the recent fuel crisis and that it has now gathered momentum. I should like to encourage the Minister to press forward in this regard in an effort to see that all the outlying services are adequately covered by motorised transport.

I should like to refer to the cut in postal services in the Cork area. From the Minister's statement I understand that it also occurred in Dublin and Dun Laoghaire. While I accept that the Department had a function to do in trying to save and conserve fuel during those critical months, the Department must also ensure that its efficiency is not impaired or that anything it does will not create problems for local people. I can recall putting letters into pillar boxes during those months — I am talking about areas where the Minister had deliveries reduced from four to two per day — and having to put in my hand to push down the letters already in that box. It would have been no problem for me, or anybody else, to take out many of those letters and throw them away.

In my opinion this was impairing the efficiency of the Department to too great an extent to comply with the situation that arose. The 50 per cent cut in the number of collections was aggravated by the timing of those collections. In some areas there was no collection from 4.45 p.m. until 1.30 p.m. the following day.

I was glad to see the Minister paying tribute to the previous Administration and I am glad that the Minister for Local Government is here to listen to that tribute. The Minister for Posts and Telegraphs stated that 101 extra postmen were created because of housing and other developments in urban areas. It certainly is a tribute to the previous Administration that there was such housing development that it necessitated the creation of 101 extra posts. I have no doubt that the Minister for Local Government has noted that compliment and that he will not now say that no houses were built by the previous Administration.

Speaker.P: There were 19,000 houses completed in the year 1972-73 as against 25,365 in 1973-74.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: The Minister for Local Government has the advantage on me because I feel sure that the Ceann Comhairle will not give me the opportunity of moving into local government affairs.
The Deputy will get an opportunity later on.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: The Minister is aware that the starts are down from 10,600 to 4,020.
In the previous year they were qualifying so that they would not have to have a certificate of valuation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: So the Minister is accepting the figures I have offered him?
Yes, I provided the figures.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I thank the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs for that tribute to the previous Administration. I am glad to note also the Minister's reference to our postal history. An effort should be made to preserve this great history.

Perhaps some speeches made by the Minister in other places are not intended to be taken as seriously as they are. Because the Minister is a man who likes surrounding himself by controversy he may not always mean what he says. However, I shall deal later with the question of our history and culture.

MainHeading.P: The Minister refers, to the waiting list for telephone installations. We seem to be losing ground in so far as this work is concerned although 30,000 new lines were connected last year which was 3,000 more than the previous year, there were still some 41,000 applications awaiting attention, an increase of 9,000 during the year so there was a net loss there of 6,000 on the previous year. I take issue with the Minister is his reference to the highest priority being given to raising the general standard even at the cost, where necessary, of restricting the intake of new subscribers. In his reply I trust that the Minister will tell us specifically where the major improvements have been carried out, in which areas of the country they have been carried out and whether, for example, improvements in the capital city have not been made at the expense of applicants in, say, Cork. The priority aspects of the situation need to be reviewed.

On a number of occasions the Minister has reminded us of the various categories that are given priority but I am aware that occasionally the queue is jumped in so far as the priority list is concerned. I would suggest that the highest priority be given to any young man starting a business. Provided a man employs six persons he will be facilitated with a telephone but in many cases the person who has the courage and initiative to go into business will be on his own or at least have fewer than six employees initially. A telephone would be of vital importance to that man and would help him in the expansion of his business; otherwise, he may have to struggle in his efforts to an extent that would not be necessary in the event of his having a telephone at his disposal.

There are other categories of persons, too, who deserve priority such as those living in remote areas and, perhaps, where there are no local transport facilities but I would put the emphasis on the man going into business because it may be very frustrating for him to be told that he has no chance of having a telephone installed for at least a year or two. Many of our big businesses have grown from small beginnings and that is another reason why we should give every encouragement in the initial stages of a business.

On page 15 of his speech the Minister refers to price increases and he attributes these to inflation. It is amazing that up to 1973 the responsibility for increases in the costs of commodities or services was placed on the Fianna Fáil Government but that since then inflation is blamed entirely for cost increases. We all know that the Minister for Finance has helped to worsen the inflationary situation. Therefore, the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs must level some of the blame for the increases in costs associated with his Department at the Minister for Finance. In a nice way the Minister is telling the public that because of inflation, because of national wage agreements and because of other increases in costs it is necessary for his Department to increase their charges.

There is a warning from the Minister of a possible increase in television licence fees and the reason for this, we are told, is that there is a diminishing volume of advertising on television. Perhaps the Minister will tell us the reasons for this situation. Would one of the reasons be a lack of finance on the part of the private sector because of various circumstances.

Speaker.P: Some advertisers are being encouraged to reduce their advertising, for example, the building societies.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Is the Parliamentary Secretary saying that that is the reason for diminishing advertising?
No.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: The Minister has not given us the reason. I accept the point made by the Parliamentary Secretary but I trust that in his reply the Minister will elaborate on this aspect.

MainHeading.P: One welcomes readily the provision in the network to allow for a choice of programmes. Those of us who live in the south are at a disadvantage in that there is not available to us a choice of channels, a facility which, by accident or otherwise, is available to people in the eastern part of the country. Another matter I have brought to the attention of the Minister on other occasions by way of supplementary questions is the matter of black spots. We are told that £1 million is being provided for the elimination of black spots. I am sure there is no need for me to elaborate on what I mean by black spots. They are the areas which because of geographic or other features, are not receiving worthwhile reception of our national television service. He hopes that considerable progress will be made in that respect this year. I pointed out to him at Question Time some time ago that in the valley from Ballygarvan to Ballinhassig, a few miles from Cork city, television reception is almost nonexistent. This is a social problem which needs to be looked at by the Department providing the television service.

I was impressed when I heard that the Minister had a little aside with the unions, and he was saying to the staff that he was the big boss and they were overdoing their demands for increases. I also thought he was unfair to the Broadcasting Review Committee. He over did his criticism of that body. He could have said that most of the report did not appeal to him. That body was appointed to do a specific job. The fact that their report was not entirely satisfactory to him, did not justify him condemning and criticising it to such an extent. Of course, he inserted a paragraph thanking them for their efforts. If I had been a member of that committee I would have felt that I had been rapped on the knuckles by the Minister and it would have been the last time I, as a citizen, would undertake to sit on a review body appointed by a Minister. I would not like to believe that the fact that this committee was appointed by his predecessor biased the Minister's thinking on this report.

A correspondent in one of the Sunday newspapers stated that for the next few days we in this House would be giving our views on specific television shows. He gave me the impression that he felt we had not the ability to judge shows or, if we had, we were only flying our kites by referring to them. I do not intend to go into detail about television programmes.

Speaker.P: Does the Deputy remember that it was the same column-ist who said Deputies looked like pigs?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I agree.
If such a remark were made by a Deputy about his profession, we would hear about it soon enough.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I agree whole-heartedly. If we as Deputies wish to express our views on television programmes he should not inhibit us any more than we inhibit him from making his comments, which are not always complimentary, in his weekly contributions to the newspaper.
We can take it but frequently his profession cannot.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I think it would be unfair to the profession to say “the profession”.
Had a comment like that been made in a general way about his or any other profession there would have been holy hell. We are supposed to take any kind of insults with good humour.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: If he had gone on to say that the Deputies may not be in a position to comment on television programmes because they do not see them as often as they might like, I could accept that point as valid. RTE is a powerful media going into many homes throughout the country. We are all biased when we look at current affairs programmes because we look at them from our own point of view. I do not think we got a fair break in the earlier months of this Government. Despite that, it is important that the programmes be topical, examine subjects in depth, be well-balanced and informative on educational and other bases. RTE provide a service which, if carried in the wrong direction, could have very serious consequences for our youth. Everyone with a young family realises how young people absorb the programmes set to suit them, just as teenagers will listen to and be guided by comments expressed on the media.

MainHeading.P: I heard the Parliamentary Secretary's contribution. He agreed that we have a culture, history and language which was dear to those who have gone before us. We have a right to preserve and respect our heritage. It deserves coverage on our television media. Its extent is not overdone, in fact, I would be inclined to say the opposite. I would hate to think that any Minister for Posts and Telegraphs would seriously suggest that this type of programme should be eliminated from our radio and television. Our culture, history and language are distinctive qualities of our life. We are in the EEC now. We, as a nation, have a right to retain and respect our heritage. If there is to be a difference between us and the European races we must preserve these particular and specific characteristics of our heritage.

There is a certain inconsistency in what the Minister says in places other than this House. During the EEC campaign he shared the same platform with those who advocated the loss of our heritage, culture and language if we entered the EEC. We said that we would like to see them preserved. Now the Minister is saying that these things no longer matter in our society.

Speaker.P: I do not think he said that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Not in this House, I agree.
I do not think he said it anywhere.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: He was quoted as saying it.
That is true. He was represented as having said that but a careful study of what he said will show——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: We have not had him deny that he said it.
He is too trusting.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I have a suspicion that he likes to be controversial. He says many things with a certain lack of sincerity, to seek headlines at certain times. I am sorry he is not in the House to hear me say that.
I recognise that the Deputy believes what he says but it is not true.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I wish to refer specifically to a bias which has been apparent, perhaps not to such a great extent in present weeks as it was some months ago. At the opening of the Irish Ballet Company season in Cork when RTE covered the opening night and showed the film subsequently the Lord Mayor of Cork, The Ministers for Education and Transport and Power and the Shadow Minister for Finance were present. The three people I have mentioned first were shown entering Cork Opera House that night. Deputy Colley, who was a former Minister for Finance and is now Shadow Minister, was barely shown at all. He was the man responsible for the State aid being given to that ballet company. He was as entitled as any of the three others to be photographed as he entered Cork Opera House. I made inquiries about the matter only to discover that the cameras were cut after the three members of the Government side had passed in. It is a small point.

It is quite a big and fair point. When we were in Opposition we were blotted off the screen every night by Deputy Molloy jumping into swimming pools. The Ministers then in office virtually took over the screen. On another occasion recently Deputy Tunney was shown. He was not by any means shoving himself forward, but he got 20 to 30 seconds coverage.
I did not see it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: The Parliamentary Secretary manages to contribute to every debate about six times. I am making a point about the exposure of the Government members on RTE; In the first three months after the change-over of the Government Ministers were shown very often on television.
I suppose people were delighted to see something different for a change.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Apparently as their images became tarnished they did not appear quite so often and the duration of their appearances were even shorter. Various statements were made over the media. To refer again to the ballet company's season at Cork it was a pity and unfair that a former Government Minister was not shown.

I agree with the Deputy if that was what happened and if it was done deliberately. If that was so, it was a pity and unfair. I do not believe that anyone in the Government has that type of control over RTE. If they tried to exercise it I do not believe RTE staff would obey them.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald

There is a little overemphasis in RTE on public affairs. They should go back to a little more entertainment. Their prime function is to entertain and through that to educate, to make education a pleasurable experience. We can do that by not taking ourselves as seriously as we do. There is no balance in the Sunday “News at One” programme. I remember being pretty disgusted when there was an item on building societies. Deputy Molloy was interviewed on the phone from his home in Galway. The Minister for Local Government, Deputy Tully, sat comfortably in the studio and was questioned about various things which Deputy Molloy said, who was not present to be able to say the Minister did not interpret correctly what he said. Speaker.P: I shall start on the note on which Deputy Briscoe has concluded. I know appeals have been made before and I know this is a matter that cannot be dealt with over-night, but nevertheless I appeal to the Minister in respect of what must be regarded as an utterly inadequate telephone service in Dublin and, I am sure, elsewhere. If we wanted to be flippant we could all admit that there were occasions on which we got a better radio programme by listening on our telephones than we actually got from Radio Éireann. I do not say that to denigrate the programmes we get from Radio Éireann. Of the two media I am much more a radio man than a television man. I say this merely to bring home to the Minister the utter and complete lack of privacy on our telephone service. In this House, I have had the experience of attempting to make a call and finding myself being answered by Deputy Gerry L'Estrange. I think one need say no more as an indication of how undesirable the position is. When one lifts a receiver one should be guaranteed one's destination and the speaker whom one is calling. One should also feel absolutely happy that, while speaking on the telephone, no third party will be involved.

MainHeading.P: This is not a problem that has appeared with this Government. It was there before the Minister took office. I mention it because I have not seen any evidence of the system having been improved in the last year or so and, from that point of view the present holder of the office must accept responsibility.

Other speakers have mentioned the frustration that arises because of inability to get through to anybody when one is so determined. Of the two I should be happier putting up with the latter rather than the former. Post Office engineers told me on one occasion that it was impossible for me, having moved only to the second digit, to get any voice at all. I am sure they now realise that what I said was perfectly true. The technicians may claim that technically it is not possible; in actual fact we know that at any stage from the time one lifts the receiver until one is finished, one is liable, putting it mildly, to hear anything and be heard by anybody.

It was, I think, Deputy Briscoe who said that he would accuse the Minister of neglect in what can be regarded as the more mundane and less glamourous duties devolving upon him. I would not agree with Deputy Briscoe in that regard, but I have one reservation to make. During the year I brought to the notice of the Minister the very unsatisfactory situation obtaining in part of my constituency in east Finglas. Local residents had been denied normal post office facilities for a period of 12 months. Actually I am not too sure that the problem has yet been resolved. I brought that to the notice of the Minister and the Minister, in his latest reply to me, indicated that the matter was now finally being attended to. If the Minister were genuinely interested in the residents of that area he should have probed a little deeper into the matter and not accepted the answers prepared for him by his officials.

Three weeks or a month ago, I had a question to the Minister about a newly developed area in south Finglas in what is called the Tolka Valley. I asked the Minister would he expedite the provision of telephone kiosks and of a post office in that area. This is a new town and those moving into it are people from all over the city. They are people who suffered many botherations in one way or another and, because of that, were offered new houses in this area. I would hope the Minister would share with me a concern for lightening the burden on these people in every way possible. Here I come to the reservation in not agreeing entirely with Deputy Briscoe, who would say that the Minister is not interested in these matters. I would say that he has an interest but I would like to see evidence of his probing instead of his accepting the answers provided for him.

When I asked the Minister for particulars as to the nearest post office in the Tolka Valley area his answer was that there were three sub-post offices within a radius of three-quarters of a mile or half a mile. Had the Minister given thought to that, he should have sent a reply to his official saying: “Look, I am not happy; this is a reply which perhaps other Ministers might accept but I realise that when one places a compass on the map and can show that there may be another sub-post office within half a mile, that does not give a clear picture of all the botheration and hardship caused to a lady who has to make the journey from her place of residence to the post office. In all probability the journey she travels may be a mile or a mile-and-a-half, as in some of the cases I instanced. If one considers the real position obtaining one must be more sympathetically disposed to the ladies, and indeed the gentlemen, who will have need of the facilities and services available to them in those post offices.

I mentioned this matter here hoping that, having brought it to the Minister's attention, he might assure me that he has given it additional consideration and, having regard to the fact that probably similar problems arise in his own developing constituency, he will probe beyond the superficial, sugared answer which all civil servants and Ministers like to give to the House but which, in my opinion, is an abuse of this House and not at all in accordance with the entitlement of the people whom we claim to represent.

On the matter of post offices and sub-post offices, there is one final point I should like to make. That is to repeat my request, in regard to the areas around Dublin city, where children's allowances are so vital to many of the mothers, that the Minister's Department and the Department of Social Welfare might agree to some system of payment which will have much more regard to the dignity of the lady whose right it is to collect children's allowances on a particular day or, indeed, on any day of the month. I do not enjoy mentioning these matters because I am fully aware that the Minister, and indeed every other Deputy, is, and should be, as sympathetic as am I to the people who suffer, and suffer they do.

In the matter of which might be regarded as priorities, I realise that one could relegate this matter to a minor position. While I accept that that attitude is prevalent and might be justified in some cases, on the other hand I freely admit that the importance of the person must claim priority over everything else. Where it can be shown that any citizen, in the pursuit of some service which is his or her entitlement finds the facilities are not in keeping with what should be accepted as our regard for our people, one cannot mention or criticise too often the shortcomings existing.

We must remember that while for the rest of us there is no such day as children's allowance day, because we are not waiting for the money, to these people there is the children's allowance day, which is the first day on which the money becomes payable. I wonder what thoughts run through the minds of the children who accompany their mothers to the post offices or sub-post offices and who find themselves standing outside—and here we must think of mid-winter conditions— in the cold and rain in queues of perhaps 50, 60, 70 or 100 yards long waiting for the payment of money which this House has decided to grant them. Again, and not to quote the words of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Welfare with whom I entirely agree this is payment of money which is in no way a charity but which is their due entitlement. Apart from what thoughts the children might have on affairs of State, I wonder what are the thoughts of the mothers who are subjected to such hardship in the collection of their children's allowances. I am quite sure it is not outside the ingenuity or capabilities of the officials of the Departments of Posts and Telegraphs and Social Welfare to introduce a form of payment which will eliminate this scandal which exists in certain areas in our city. One is forced to the impression, too, that if the hardship existed in what might be regarded as the more residential parts of our city the matter would not need such repetition as it has received in this House.

In whatever period of office remains to the Minister of Posts and Telegraphs my indebtedness to him will arise more on the score of whatever action he may take and I would be more convinced that the true spirit of socialism was manifesting itself in his regard for people if I had evidence that action had been taken in regard to these matters, especially the payment of children's allowances. If action is taken in that respect then to me, apart from all else, his period in office as Minister for Posts and Telegraphs will have been justified.

There is a Chinese proverb about the man who was continually watching the stars and not seeing what was happening at his feet. So far as my remarks up to this referred exclusively to what may be regarded as being at my feet I am now moving to matters which, correctly or otherwise, are regarded as being on a higher level. Much has been said about the influence of television and radio and about the power and the merit of communication. I must admit to having some doubts recently about whether the influence is altogether as powerful as we think it is. I am talking now on planes which are perhaps philosophical, not about the power of television or radio to sell records or create pop kings and queens, but about its power to influence people in a worthy and lasting way. I can see both agencies exercising a certain influence, which might be regarded as ephemeral, but whether we should accept that radio or television do much more than entertain or agitate the mind—but only to a point of convincing one that the ideas, thoughts and impressions which one has and the wisdom which one thinks one has captured are still the best—I do not know.

Presumably if television and radio do nothing more than confirm the viewer or listener in the wisdom of his prevailing thoughts, it is giving a service but I do not think we should accept that unless we gear television and radio in a certain way it can lead to our ultimate destruction or to dispelling all worthwhile thought or, on the other hand, that it is an agency that can be geared to the creation of a climate or educational atmosphere superior to all else. Recently somebody said he thought television was driving people to pubs. I do not accept that but his point was that because of the intrusion of television on domestic and household conversations and pastimes, people were less inclined to welcome certain programmes. People had now become accustomed to thought being compartmentalised for them. They were obliged to sit and listen to or look at people who regarded themselves or might be regarded by others as the sole custodians of all that was correct. They found themselves listening to or watching programmes which ostensibly were designed to educate and seemed ab initio to set out to prove conclusively that this or that was the true position and excluded all else but instead of its reaching over a wide area—which it would claim to do— the manner in which questions were put limited the discussion. If the person being interviewed wanted to move outside the limits set by the presenter of the programme such comment was not welcome. People are beginning to move away from that kind of programme. They do not feel any sense of participation in it. While I do not agree with the person who said such programmes were driving people to the pubs, I accept that the point he was making was valid to the extent that there are not sufficient programmes in which the viewer or the listener can become really involved.

Deputy Briscoe referred to morning programmes. In the last year I have been listening to these programmes and, although they appear to think they can cure certain tensions that exist in society at the moment, it is impossible to listen to them and not feel under severe tension. Instead of helping towards the elimination of stress, it could be argued that some of the programmes and the topics discussed leave the listener with a far greater degree of tension after the programmes have concluded.

Here we are faced with the problems that arise when one considers the programmes that will satisfy the listener or the viewer. Unfortunately, human beings have an immediate attraction towards morbidity, the gruesome or news items that are distasteful in themselves. Here the Minister might intervene and indicate that it is not necessary all the time to pander to what gives ephemeral or immediate satisfaction; rather the obligation lies in providing a more lasting, wholesome and beneficial satisfaction.

Reference has been made to what was described as the Minister's Waterford speech. I am happy that since that speech, or more correctly that alleged speech, the Minister has indicated to this House and elsewhere that, to say the least, there has been some misunderstanding as to what was said.

Speaker.P: I can supply the Deputy with the text of my alleged speech. It was a speech and the full text is available.

Later I would appreciate a copy but it will not deter me now from continuing in this vein. Here is evidence of what I referred to earlier and of the attraction that lies for television, radio and the Press to report what might be newsworthy rather than something that is abolutely factual. If that is what happened well and good, but I think the Minister would accept that from general reporting of the speech it was assumed and accepted that he was unusually critical of the Irish content of radio and television programmes. Apart from that, the Minister was reported as having accused the people in television and radio who deal with programmes in Irish of a domineering attitude——
The Deputy is quoting from a misrepresentation which appeared in one paper only.

I thought it strange in that speech that if the Minister had evidence he did not refer to the reaction of the listeners and viewers to these programmes. I have not heard any criticism from people regarding the amount of Irish in programmes. On the contrary, I have heard many comments and many expressions of disappointment that we have not many more programmes. People whose knowledge of Irish is not that wonderful have said that the programme “Féach” is one of the best television programmes. Subsequent to the Minister's speech, I had hoped to get information on the TAM ratings of a programme such as “Féach” but, unfortunately, the Ceann Comhairle's office advised me it was not a matter for the Minister to give these details. I hope that it is now in order for me to refer to the matter so that the Minister in his reply might give us some information regarding the reaction of the people. I am not talking about the Gaelic leaders, the Gaelgeoirí, Conradh na Gaeilge or Comhdháil Náisiúnta na Gaeilge or what might be regarded as a lobbying group. I am not concerned about them at this point, or their alleged desire to impose Irish on the people. I am anxious to get from the Minister the people's reaction to these programmes.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna-Questions. Oral Answers. - Cattle Mart Sales.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if, when cattle are sold at marts without TB or brucellosis cards, it is the general practice in his Department to perform a test and issue new cards without warble fly certificates.

It is illegal to expose cattle at any public sale unless they are accompanied by the proper identity cards in relation to bovine tuberculosis and, where appropriate, brucellosis and also the appropriate certificate of treatment for warble fly infestation.

In regard to TB or brucellosis certification, when undocumented or improperly documented animals are discovered at marts the animals are returned to their owners and, if the proper documentation cannot be produced, further movement of the animals and other cattle in the herd to which they belong is restricted by my Department until such time as they have passed the relevant test for TB and, if applicable, brucellosis. There is no means other than a treatment certificate of establishing whether the animals had been dressed at the proper time for warble fly infestation and unless the appropriate documentation is available in respect of the animals concerned they cannot be accepted for public sale.

Is the Minister satisfied that these regulations are being carried out? There is a feeling in the west that these regulations are not being complied with, that there is too much mixing going on and, as a result, we are failing to make any progress with the eradication of brucellosis.
We have people employed in the various marts throughout the country to do this job of inspection. They have been warned time and again and I hope they are doing their job.
Cattle cannot get into a mart without the necessary qualifications.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna-Questions. Oral Answers. - European Commission Spokesmen Comments.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O.J. Flanagan Mr. O.J. Flanagan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will make representations to the European Commission to ensure that Commission spokesmen will not comment in future on internal affairs of this country, such as the budget.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Dr. FitzGerald) Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: Under the provisions of the treaties establishing the European Communities, to which the Irish Government adhere in accordance with the decision of the Irish people, the council may, acting unanimously on a proposal from the commission, decide upon the measures appropriate to the conjunctural situation in the Community. Where these measures have been adopted unanimously by the council, the commission have the further function of proposing directives for action to give effect to these measures, these proposals being subject to adoption by the council by a qualified majority. Finally, in addition to these provisions of Article 103 of the EEC Rome Treaty, Article 155 requires the commission, in order to ensure the proper functioning and development of the Common Market, to formulate recommendations or deliver opinions on matters dealt with in the Rome Treaty, to the extent that the treaty expressly so provides or if the commission considers it necessary to do so. The commission, of course, have other functions under other articles of treaties.

The representations which the Deputy proposes that I should make would accordingly be inappropriate as they would involve seeking to dissuade the commission from carrying out the functions conferred on it by the treaties to which we have adhered in response to the wishes of the Irish people.
It was not clear from the text of the Minister's reply. Under what heading of their responsibilities the particular representation to which Deputy Flanagan objects were made?

Article 103. There are a number of articles which can be involved and under which the commission have certain functions with regard to member States. Article 103 on conjunctural policy seems to be the relevant article.
Will the Minister read Article 103 again please?

The article states that member States should regard their conjunctural policies as a matter of common concern. They should consult each other and the commission on the measures to be taken in the light of prevailing circumstances.
That does not seem to give the commission any authority to make the sort of statement to which Deputy Flanagan objected.
I do not agree with the Deputy. I do not necessarily agree with the contents of the statements which may not have been——
I am not concerned about that.

The conjunctural policy in member States of the Community is the responsibility of the commission. They are entitled to give their views as to how member States should operate in this particular area. They are within their rights, whatever one might think of their judgment of our economic situation.

Did I understand the Minister to say there had to be agreement among the commissioners? In this particular case when a spokesman referred to our budget, had it been considered by the commission as a whole and had there been agreement on what he said?
Any action of the commission under the Rome Treaties has to be carried out by a formal decision of the commission acting for the majority. That must have taken place in this as in any other case.
Did it?
I distinguish here between statements by spokesmen of the community on particular issues and formal action by the community.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna-Questions. Oral Answers. - EEC Access Negotiations.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O.J. Flanagan Mr. O.J. Flanagan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if there are serious implications for this country in the deadlock which has now been reached in negotiations between the EEC and 44 African, Caribbean and Pacific island states concerning the key issues of access for agricultural products and arrangements for trade in raw materials; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Negotiations under Protocol 22 of the Accession Treaty concerning relations between the European Economic Community and its member States on the one hand and the Associated African and Malagasy States and the independent Commonwealth countries in Africa, the Indian and Pacific Oceans and the Caribbean on the other, were formally inaugurated by the conference in Brussels on 25th and 26th July, 1973. Substantive negotiations commenced in Brussels in the autumn and are continuing.

MainHeading.P: It is not true to say that deadlock has been reached. The position is that while considerable progress has been made in a number of areas, the community had difficulty in adopting final negotiating positions on some issues which are of a vital concern to the negotiating partners, and this led to expressions of dissatisfaction by them which have been reported in the Press. The outstanding issues have included those of access for some agricultural products and the stabilisation of export earnings or some other means to safeguard the interests of those negotiating partners whose economies depend to a considerable extent on the export of primary products. The community's offer for the outstanding agricultural product was, however, finalised at the Council of Ministers meeting in Luxembourg the day before yesterday, 4th June, and the way is now open to discuss this offer with the negotiating partners. The effect of the community's proposals would be to accord the partner States a special regime, on a product by product basis, more favourable than the general regime applied to third countries with the necessary safeguards to protect community interests. With regard to the stabilisation issue, this is, of course, a very complex and technical problem but it is one of great importance to some of the negotiating States and particularly to the poorer among them. The commission is shortly to complete its proposals as to community action in this field and I would hope that the council will subsequently be in a position to take an early decision on the proposals to be made in the negotiations which may resume at ministerial level before the end of next month.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna-Questions. Oral Answers. - Irish Troops Peace-Keeping Duties.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will make a statement on the role Irish troops will play in carrying out peace-keeping duties in future under the control of the United Nations.

The Government are fully committed to the policy of affording all possible support to United Nations peace-keeping efforts and we would, therefore, be anxious to respond positively to any requests for troops that the United Nations might make to us in the future.

At present, Irish officers and men are participating in the work of the United Nations Truce Supervision Organisation in the Middle East and of the United Nations Force in Cyprus. In addition, I am very glad to be able to inform the House that an Irish officer has now been appointed to the post of interim Chief-of-Staff of the newly-created United Nations Disengagement Observation Force, which will supervise the disengagement agreement between Israel and Syria signed in Geneva on Friday last, 31st May.

With regard to the United Nations Emergency Force in the Middle East, the Government decided, following the bombings in Dublin and Monaghan last month, to ask for the temporary release of the Irish contingent there. The Secretary-General fully appreciates the circumstances under which these troops are required for service at home. We informed him that when the present need has passed, we would be happy to send an Irish contingent again to the Middle East. Our commitment to the United Nations Emergency Force we regard as continuing, even though we are not for the present in a position to supply troops to that force.

MainHeading.P: I should like to avail myself of this opportunity to tell the House that the Secretary-General publicly paid tribute to the officers and men of the Irish contingent in the emergency force for the manner in which they discharged their difficult task in the Middle East. I need hardly add that this tribute is fully endorsed by the Government, as indeed, it is, I am sure, by every member of the House.

Speaker.P: The Deputy is making a statement.

MainHeading.P: Debate resumed on the following motion:

—(Minister for Posts and Telegraphs.)

Speaker.P: I was suggesting earlier to the Minister that it is necessary for him to indicate more clearly the essence of what has now come to be regarded as “the Waterford speech”. I was hoping he would be patient with me while I repeated something which I have already said in this House. If there is one thing more than any other which must be catered for on radio and television, it is our sense of Irishness. I was very happy to listen to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Taoiseach expressing his thoughts on this. In the main they coincide with mine. I would not be anxious to divorce myself from anything which I considered wise and profound coming from the other side of the House.

I said earlier that I did not accept that television or radio has an absolutely powerful influence. I did not deny that it has an influence. It has an aggregate influence which must be regarded as an important factor in the ultimate. In the matter of catering for and fostering things which are regarded as being Irish, its function must never be forgotten. If the history not only of this country but of the world shows anything, it shows the folly of disregarding the past. There are certain aspects of the past attaching to every country which one would like to forget and which one should forget. The normal and natural feeling of emotion which every Irishman and Irish woman has, idealistic towards that which is best for the people of Ireland, cannot and should never be disregarded. More positively it should be catered for. In catering for that which might be regarded as idealistic, you are also performing a very useful social, economic and cultural exercise.

MainHeading.P: If it appears to people that this provision is not being made, you create in the minds of some a feeling of despair or indifference, and you create in the minds of others a feeling of resistance and anger and a certain militancy which could be more than dangerous. In so far as the Minister may have given wrong impressions, or wrong impressions may have been created about him, I should like him to assure me that he is in full sympathy with RTE's obligations to cater for this feeling which we all have. I am not suggesting that we should cater for the fanatic or the impossible character. I am not suggesting that we should cater for the person who, in harbouring certain thoughts, would constitute a bother and a danger to his neighbour.

We are obliged to cater for the moderate Irish person who has this feeling within him, whether it manifests itself on the day when Ireland is involved in an international soccer match, or on the day when Ronnie Delaney is representing Ireland at the Olympic Games, or in the pride we feel when somebody who can claim Irish descent is elevated to the highest position in America. There is in the heart and in the mind of every Irish person a desire and a craving that Ireland should be free, with its own identity, and with an attitude towards life as good as and, if possible, superior to the attitude to life in any other country. Arising from that there would be a family feeling and we would have regard for each other as members of a family.

It is sad that anybody should have to stand up here and state that position. From my knowledge there is no example to be found in history of a nation who were prepared— unless they had to yield to greater force—to part with that which they regarded, and which must properly be regarded, as peculiar to themselves. Because of this I suggest to the Minister that it is an area which cannot be approached in any cold, clinical fashion. I freely admit that it is an emotional area and emotional areas and feelings generally do not lend themselves to any cold, clinical analysis. I am stating the position as I see it. I am not claiming that what I see is always, or in this case the absolutely correct view. It would be very presumptuous of me to do that but I suggest that what I am stating is as near to being correct as anything else I have stated from those who hold opposing views to mine.

I have stated on radio programmes, and in this House, before Deputy Cruise-O'Brien became a Minister, that in the matter of things Irish he was one of the few Deputies who spoke the Irish language. I heard his views expressed before he became a Minister and I never had any reason to doubt that his feelings would largely coincide with mine. Therefore, it is with reluctance that I express my anxiety and ask the Minister to make clear his position.

In treating this matter solely from the practicalities of it, it should be mentioned that in respect of section 31 people are not too happy with the situation where we get a man who is regarded by most people as being a good sound and intelligent Irishman, Seán Ó Riordáin, not being allowed take part in a television programme.

Speaker.P: That was not the point. The point was that he made a statement in support of the Provisional IRA which statement was deleted from the interview as broadcast and not that there was any objection to him as a person but to this particular sentiment.
The Minister is making what I regard as a subtle distinction. When I say that he was denied full expression on an RTE programme——
If the Deputy says that it is correct.

He was denied full expression on an RTE programme because, it is alleged, he was commenting in a favourable fashion on an organisation which could be accused of intimidation and violence. On the other hand, it is well known to everybody, and this is the problem as I see it, that representatives of the intimidating violent loyalists can be brought down here at expense and given every opportunity to present themselves in a full and free fashion to the viewers. Where is the balance? Where is the impartiality there?

MainHeading.P: In the matter of intimidation and violence I would not differentiate between the provisionals and the loyalists. I hope the Minister will indicate why he accepts that on one hand RTE should arrange for and thank representatives of one intimidating violent group for having taken part in a programme while on the other hand they excluded a gentleman, a scholar and an Irishman of the calibre of Seán Ó Riordáin. In so far as this specific case may create the circumstances of building up in the minds and in the hearts of a certain section of people an eagerness for violence, annoyance and frustration as expressed in a manner which is not correct and does not appeal to us, I am trying to present to the Minister the need there is for at least maintaining an appearance of impartiality.

The Minister is a fair man and he has sat through the debate on his Estimate in a patient fashion but I hope he will allow himself to accept some of the ideas from this side of the House. I venture to suggest that he will accept that by appearing to act in an unjust fashion — here I refer specifically to the area of Ireland largely catered for by RTE — and that if a case can be made that this is taking place one automatically builds up in the minds of the people what they would regard as cause and reason for them to give expression to their frustration in an undesirable fashion.

In a more everyday comment I want to record my own personal annoyance and displeasure when I hear competent television and radio commentators talking about Ireland, about people in Ireland, or about counties assuming what I would regard as an old west Britonish attempt at an Irish brogue. As far as I am concerned that attitude has gone and there is an obligation on them as Irish commentators and as Irishmen to act in the same fashion towards Ireland as the manner in which their counterparts in England act towards England, but they must be careful that in so doing they do not regard Ireland as a part of England and that they do not imitate their English counterparts in the attitude they might have towards Irish bogmen.

Ar nóta a bhaineas le díomá, caithfidh mé a rá go bhfuil brón orm nach raibh an tAire in ann níos mó airgead a chur ar fáil do Radio na Gaeltachta. Tá a fhios agam go bhfuil suim aige atá ioncurtha leis an suim atá agamsa i Radio na Gaeltachta. Tuigfidh sé mar sin an díomá atá ormsa nach bhfuil ar a laghad an t-árdu céanna sin i gcúrsaí airgid a líonfadh an bhearna atá ann maidir le h-úsáidh airgid le bliain anuas, comh fada is a bhaineann sé le muintir na Gaeltachta. Bhí mé féin thiar. Bhí mé ó dheas. Bhí mé ó thuaidh agus ag caint le daoine thuig mé, sé sin i rith na bliana, gur cheapadar go bhféadfaidís i bhfad níos mó oibre a dhéanamh ach níos mó airgead a bheith acu. Gan trácht air sin ar chor ar bith, tá ceist na síceolaíochta ann. Seans go gceapfaidh siad anois, de bhrí nach bhfuil aon ardú airgid ann, nach bhfuil an oiread sin suime againn iontu agus ba cheart. Más féidir le Radio na Gaeltachta a thaispeáint go bhfuil pleananna acu nó go bhfuil ar intinn acu cláracha speisialta a chur ar fáil nach féidir leo a dhéanamh anois cheal airgid an mbeadh an tAire sásta a rá leo go gcuirfeadh sé féin an t-airgead sin ar fáil?

Speaker.P: Ar dtús, ba mhaith liom traoslú leis an Aire maidir leis an gcaoi ar chuir sé na Meastacháin os comhair na Dála. Tá sé soiléir dúinn uilig an chaoi ina bhfuil an caiteachas sin déanta agus tá sé i bhfad níos fusa a thuiscint cén chaoi go bhfuil obair na Roinne atá faoi na chúram ar siúl. Ach, faraoir, caithfidh mé stopadh ansin nuair a théann sé go dtí moladh mar nuair a léigh mé óráid an Aire feicim go bhfuil mé ag rá na rudaí adúirt mé anuraidh mórán, go bhfuil na deacrachtaí céanna ann, go bhfuil na rudaí céanna a luadh anseo anuraidh, go bhfuil siad mar a bhí siad cheana agus gur beag dul chun cinn atá déanta sa Roinn seo. Dúradh go mbeadh pleananna ag an Aire le cuid mhaith rudaí a dhéanamh ach is oth liom a rá nach mar sin atá an scéal. Is beag buntáiste a fheicim ón chaiteachas seo sa Roinn Poist agus Telegrafa.

MainHeading.P: Luaigh an Teachta Tunney Radio na Gaeltachta. Tá díomá orm faoin gcaoi go bhfuil faillí déanta arís maidir le caiteachas i dtaobh Radio na Gaeltachta. Caitfidh mé, mar a rinne mé anuraidh, tagairt ar leith a dhéanamh do Chontae Mhaigheo. Níl aon tseirbhís le fáil ansin againn ó Radio na Gaeltachta. Cé gur muid an tríú Gaeltacht is mó sa tír is féidir liom a rá nach bhfuil mórán teangmháil againn ná mórán cuidiú dá thabhairt dúinn ó Radio na Gaeltachta.

Tá a fhios agam go bhfuil deacrachtaí ag an bhfoireann atá ag obair ansin ceal airgid. Níl an gléas ceart oibre acu agus déarfainn dá mbeadh an tseirbhís chéanna ar siúl acu agus atá anseo i mBaile Átha Cliath agus deis acu mar atá acu anseo i mBaile Átha Cliath go bhféadfadh siad i bhfad níos mó a dhéanamh. I láthair na h-uaire níl aon phost faoi leith ag cuid de na daoine atá ag obair ansin. Caithfidh siad dul amach agus eolas a bhailiú, ábhar chlár a bhailiú agus ansin caithfidh siad teacht isteach go dtí an stáisiún féin agus an clár sin a chur os comhair an phobail. Níl aon deis acu mar atá anseo i mBaile Átha Cliath. Níl aon chaoi ceart acu le na gcuid cláracha a réiteach agus lena gcur os comhair an phobail. Dá bhrí sin, go leor den ábhar a cuirtear amach ag Radio na Gaeltachta baineann sé leis an rud céanna i gcónaí. Níl aon leagan amach ar smaointe ná ar obair ná ar an ábhar atá á chur os comhair an phobail agus ní aon locht é sin ar na daoine atá ag plé leis an Radio ansin. Faoi mar adúirt mé níl an t-airgead acu agus níl an deis oibre acu. Is mór an trua nach bhfuil níos mó deis ag na daoine éisteacht leis na cláracha breátha a chuireann Radio na Gaeltachta ar fáil.

Sílim ó thaobh na mbunscoileanna go mba bhreá an rud é dá mbeadh clár ann a mbeadh deis ag na páistí scoile éisteacht leis i rith am scoile. Ar an gcaoi chéanna ins na meánscoileanna, agus ins na gairmscoileanna ba bhreá an rud é dá bhféadfaí ceol, amhráin, an saibhreas cainte agus Gaeilge atá ag muintir na Gaeltachta a chloisint i rith am scoile. Sílim go mba cheart don Aire féachaint chuige go mbeadh níos mó airgead le fáil aige ón Aire Airgeadais más féidir, fiú amháin go gcuirfí airgead ar fáil tré mheastacháin Aire na Gaeltachta leis na seirbhísí seo a leathnú agus a chur ar fáil do chuile dhuine.

Anois gheall an tAire go bhféachfadh sé chuige go ndéanfaí rud éigin i gContae Mhaigheo. Ón tuarascáil seo is cosúil nach bhfuil sé ar intinn tada a gheallúint i mbliana ach ní bheidh mé sásta agus coinneodh mé leis an Aire nó go bhfaighe mé freagra a bhéas sásúil maidir leis na Gaeltachtaí i gContae Mhaigheo. Cé go bhfuil muid ó thaobh daonradh dó ar an tríú Gaeltacht is mó sa tír tá an deacracht seo ann go bhfuil muid scaipthe. Tá Tuar Mhic Éadaigh i bpóca leis féin, tá Acaill—an méid atá fágtha dó mar Ghaeltacht, tá Ceathrú Thaidhg agus áiteacha eile ar chósta thuaidh Mhuigheo, agus an chuid den Ghaeltacht atá ar an taobh thiar de leithinis Bhéal a' Mhuirthid tá siad scaipthe óna chéile agus ar an gcaoi sin deineann sé an scéal níos measa mar go bhfuil siad istigh i lár áiteacha a bhfuil an Béarla ag fáil an bhua orthu. Níl siad cosúil le Gaeltachtaí Chonamara ná Gaeltachtaí Thír Chonaill atá dlúth agus atá lonnaithe in aon áit amháin.

Dá bhrí sin, sílim nuair a bhí an rud seo faoi Radio na Gaeltachta faoi scrudú an chéad uair nár tugadh aitheantas go leor do na deacrachtaí i gContae Mhaigheo. Tá mé ag iarraidh ar an Aire arís go ndéanfaidh sé scrúdú faoi leith ar an scéal agus go mbeidh freagra níos fearr le fáil agam ná fuair mé go dtí seo.

Ó thárla ag caint mé faoi Ghaeilge agus Gaeltachtaí, sílim go bhfuil rud amháin fúinn. Ní thugann muid go leor aitheantas do cheist seo na Gaeilge. Tá tuiscint i bhfad níos fearr ar Ghaeilge sa tír ná mar is eol do dhaoine. Sílim gur beag rud gur féidir le duine a rá ar an Radio ná i n-áit ar bith eile nach mbeidh tuiscint air agus ar an ábhar sin sílim go gcuideodh sé go mór le ceist na Gaeilge dá mbeadh daoine in ann níos mó den Ghaeilge a labhrann muintir na Gaeltachta a chloisteáil ar an Radio. Tá gá dá bhrí sin leis an gcuidiú seo. Tá gá leis an scéal a athbhreithniú agus lena leathnú amach le hais mar atá sé.

Níor mhaith liom go dtuigfeadh daoine ná go sílfeadh daoine go raibh mé ag caitheamh drochmheas ar na daoine atá ag obair ar son Radio na Gaeltachta. Go deimhin, a mhalairt atá ann. Sé an rud atá ar siúl agam go bhfuil mé ag iarraidh a thaispeáint na deacrachtaí atá acu agus an obair dheacair atá acu san obair atá ar siúl acu. Tá rud eile ann. Tá go leor taistil le déanamh acu agus cuireann sé seo isteach go mór ar gach gné den chaoi atá acu le cláracha a réiteach agus a chur os comhair an phobail.

Maidir le radio i gcoitinne sílim go bhfuil an-obair á déanamh ag an radio féin. Tá na cláracha atá acu ar an radio suimiúil. Tá go leor leor gné de shaol na ndaoine á chur os comhair an phobail. Tá gach cineál obair agus gnoithe atáar siúl sa tír, tá sé ag fáil aitheantas ar an radio. Is mór an moladh atá ag dul na daoine atá i mbun cláracha ar an radio. Go deimhin, tá a fhios agam féin go bhfuil daoine ag cailliúint go leor leor cláracha breátha radio i ngeall ar an dteilifís mar tá faisean ag daoine nuair a osclaíonn an teilifís tráthnóna é a chasadh ar siúl agus bíonn sé ar siúl i gcaitheamh na hoíche. I ngeall ar sin cailleann siad cuid mhaith cláracha breátha a bhíonn ar siúl ar an radio.

People who do not listen to radio programmes are missing a great deal. I find radio programmes have great value from an entertainment point of view, the standard is very high. There is more versatility on radio than on television. Too often we are inclined to switch on television when the programmes commence in the afternoon or evening and that is a shame. In this way many good radio programmes are missed.

The people responsible for this service are doing an excellent job in providing entertainment and programmes of a high educational value. I cannot say the same for television. Our television service at the moment could be regarded as another branch of the BBC. We do not appear to have very much originality. Our home-produced programmes are often of a very high quality. In the main our television service is not providing the service we expect.

Sports programmes as a rule are entertaining. The programme produced on Sunday night was, at one time, a sports programme where one got a fairly good balance as regards the various games being played. The GAA and other sports got a fair share of the time. For some reason some bright genius decided to introduce a programme which to me appears to be an attempted comedy act rather than a sports programme. I used to enjoy this particular sports programme, but since the introduction of this new programme, it has deteriorated considerably and can now hardly be classed as a sports programme. As a national service we are entitled to see programmes which relate to the Irish way of life.

One very seldom sees a good play in English or Irish. The amount of Irish music and songs which we get is fairly limited. We could hardly be satisfied with the amount of time devoted to the Irish language. It is necessary for the authority to consider these things seriously and not to make us just another branch of the BBC.

With regard to telephone services and the post office, I find myself making the same references and complaints today that I made here last year when this Estimate was presented to the House. A sum of £7.5 million has been provided for the telephone services. Quite honestly I cannot see any marked improvement in the area which I represent.

Speaker.P: It takes between two to three years for such investment to have an effect which is felt by the consumers.

I accept that. The importance of proper communications for industry and tourism and life in general in remote areas must be taken into account. Letters from the Department which I receive in reply to questions contain stock answers with regard to the provision of public telephones and the extension of services for people in rural areas. Last year the Minister when replying on his Estimate asked for some criteria from Deputies with regard to the provision of public telephones. At that time suggestions were made. I myself decided that where there is a national school serving an area of 70 or 80 houses this could be taken as a unit where a public telephone or kiosk could be erected. Going on that basis I have written to the Department and on various occasions put down parliamentary questions asking to have telephones provided in such areas. Again I find that the stock reply is that the Department's policy is to provide a telephone kiosk only where there is a post office. There is not much benefit to the public in having a telephone kiosk erected just outside a post office. In many instances the post offices in rural areas have been there for hundreds of years. No extra service is being provided by having the telephone service outside except that some assistance is being given to the sub-post mistress. She is being given an opportunity of finishing at 5.30 p.m. instead of continuing until 10.30 p.m. to facilitate the people coming to make telephone calls. There should be some new thinking on this.

Rural areas are very much hampered because of the lack of these services. They are necessary and should be provided without delay. If I, as a public representative, have to go before the public and give them the Department's excuse with regard to the matter I am afraid they will think very little of it. The telephone is a necessary part of life in a rural community.

MainHeading.P: Today I had two parliamentary questions to the Minister relating to this matter. The Minister explained why it is not possible to provide telephones in the two areas I mentioned. It is because a special cable would have to be put down. I accept this. The two areas I mentioned are Gaeltacht areas. Gaeltarra Éireann are doing a tremendous job trying to have industry brought to the Gaeltacht. They are working hard on this. They have a programme to have all the people of the Gaeltacht working in the early eighties. The telephone is one of the things that industrialists ask about. An industrialist will ask about communications and facilities. If a man is a farmer who wants to rear his family in a particular area where he sets up he needs such services. Apart altogether from the fact that it is important for industry it is also important from the social side. One of the things that counts a good deal with people making inquiries about setting up any particular industry is the availability of telephones. It is also very important for tourism. We find that the Americans are constantly complaining about our telephone service.
Progress reported; Committee to sit again.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answer. - ESB Charges.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Transport and Power if he is aware that in a recanvass of the Meathill and Drumcondrath areas, County Meath, the ESB has demanded a capital contribution totalling £2,295 from 16 applicants for supply; and whether he considers this charge to be excessive especially in view of the fact that an old age pensioner is being asked to pay £335.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport and Power (Mr. P. Barry) Peter Barry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Transport and Power (Mr. P. Barry)
Speaker.P: I am informed by the ESB that terms for supply under the final phase of the rural electrification scheme have recently been quoted to applicants in Meathill rural area. The terms quoted to each applicant are based on the cost of extending supply to the applicants' premises and include a special service as well as the normal fixed charge.

The capital payments referred to by the Deputy apply in cases where the applicants were given the option of buying out their special service charges but they are under no obligation to avail of this offer.

In one case the applicant was quoted a capital contribution of £459.02. This payment is required to buy out part of the special service charge as the cost of extending supply to his premises is very high, in the region of £1,200.
